Message.Title: I owned Dell from 1997 to 2004.
Message.Msg: What a ride that was! Tripled my sizeable investment. Wish I had seen the top at $57 and got out, but rode it down to $34 before I sold. My average cost was $11 and now it's under that. The business cycle is very interesting, don't ya think? I wonder if Dell can ever come back. Any thoughts?

Message.Title: Intel reduces 4Q pc demand - (quote - link)
Message.Msg: Intel Corp.'s profit dropped 14% in the third quarter, underscoring tough times for the personal computer sector amid competition from tablet-style devices and other headwinds. The big chip maker, whose microprocessors power most desktop PCs and laptops, said it is significantly scaling back production in the fourth quarter in response to weaker than expected demand. Intel said that move will cause it to take $500 million in charges for excess production capacity, triggering a big decline in its closely watched gross profit margin for the quarter.

Message.Title: The total PC market is "estimated" to decline by ONLY 1.2% in 2012 vs 2011....
Message.Msg: According to IHS isuppli, the leading IT market research firm, all this noise about the death of PC is pure nonsense as it expects 348.7 million units to be shipped in 2012 calender year vs 352.8 units shipped in 2011 which was the highest in a decade.... So all the lies by the shorts has provided smart money to buy DELL cheap and in the meantine have the shorts meet their maker in the process. BUY all you can!

Message.Title: Analysts at IDC: The launch of Windows 8 will boost PC sales by 6.5% going into 2013....
Message.Msg: “In other words, for 2013, the market otherwise would have been flat,” Daoud told ReadWriteWeb. “But for Windows 8, we boost it by about 5%, so that gives it 5% growth. That’s essentially the premium given to Windows 8.” IDC now estimates that that worldwide PC shipment growth will average 7.1% from 2013-2016. Next year, however, worldwide PC sales in units should jump from -1.2% this year to 6.5%, with growth accelerating to 7.0% and 7.5% in 2014 and 2015, respectively. Much of that demand will come from emerging markets, whose residents are still buying their first PCs, as well as purchasing Windows 8 replacements for those they already own, Windows XP, Vista and W-7.
